replies.author: @shadowlord2323
replies.text:
@Sergeant Pickles

You're not wrong, a lotta white nationalists/white supremacists and other far right types usually associated with them don't have very good lives and often have had trouble developing and melding in with society growing up. My own parents didn't do a good job teaching me how to properly care for myself and I had ADHD that messed up my ability to process lessons correctly growing up. I grew up in a Republican family so naturally leaned right. When I encountered actual fascists initially I was careful but within a few years I was into their ideology and explored everything from fascism to monarchism, all sorts of autocratic governments. There was lots of racism, sexism, talk of civil war and martyrdom, embracing emotion. 

Then the days came I really started questioning myself and over time I grew away from those people till it finally happened. I didn't wanna be this sort of person because as I thought more about it I just didn't see any other solution than a bleak outlook on life and death. It's trying to apply the rules of the natural world to man. The strongest only fit to survive. Fascism feeds off that sorta world because they wanna force you to sacrifice your empathy and basic humanity for the sake of making their group the strongest so you can do away with all the others they don't want in the world. You're just a pawn for that ultimate goal and what ultimately happens to you is of little concern to the greater tribe. 

I came to the conclusion that yes, there are wingnuts and foolishness in the left just as there are in the right, but ultimately the left is right. We have a responsibility to those more worse off than us and shouldn't desire the destruction of other people just because differences in opinion, sex, color, etc. We're human beings, and those of us that succeed in life should find our fulfillment out of helping our fellow man. We don't have to live by the laws of nature, we have a choice in how we conduct ourselves. You have a choice to be compassionate, you have a choice to be understanding. Even if your job isn't great and family a trainwreck you can still be someone's personality to look up to when they wake up today. The nationalists and autocrats want you to cast aside that choice and embrace bigotry and overall make life more miserable collectively for us all and for what? Because they're bitter about their status in life? Because they weren't successful? Who are they to judge what success is? You can be the poorest man in the world yet have your soul, and I choose to have my soul rather than embrace their ideology because in the end I'd rather be poor then have to live with myself burning with hatred for other people.

Ultimately I think the left's big issue today is falling into a pit trap alienating whites seeing them as hopelessly attracted to nationalism and bigotry. Given the left in the USA has a preference for talking minority rights and issues over whites and their troubles, I believe that plays a role in why many young whites go fascist/bigot. They see themselves as left behind by everyone outside their group. The only way the left can counter that is to simply embrace it's core principles. Compassion and charity. Treat everyone who needs help as they need it regardless of where they are in life and turn the other cheek when they act foolishly. That's even a Christian principle at it's core with turning the other cheek and showing compassion, but many American Christians have lost sight of that becoming embroiled in right wing populism and American nationalism. I grew distant from religion because of those things but I still see the application of being Christlike and what the left can achieve with it. We are not here to live according to the natural world, we can live outside of it's rules and make our own as mankind. Those rules ought to be bent and broken for the sake of our fellow man. Of course we need to stand against the radicals when they try pushing their hate, but ultimately they will only get far if we fuel their fire. This is the great society that in the end we all ought to strive for and it starts in each of us individually.

As an older time-traveler from the ‚Äò70s, I can tell you: reaching out to and educating these people, and offering them some hope ‚Äî expanding their minds and imaginations, helping them correctly identify who‚Äôs exploiting them, assisting them in envisioning a better civilization ‚Äî is much harder than reviling them, but ultimately the only path forward. Those people aren‚Äôt enemies, but potential allies who simply haven‚Äôt been enlightened yet.

Yes, among them there are professional recruiters ‚Äî who‚Äôll resist you no matter what, and who‚Äôll make sure their recruits, at least in public, all toe the line and revile you too. But you must be stoic and stalwart and polite in persisting, because in private some of those recruits will begin to see cracks in their recruiters‚Äô ideology, and many will have been ambivalent all along, and some WILL reach out to you‚Ä¶ and a few will even join you!

(And here‚Äôs where you must be extra-vigilant, because the newest recruits, especially refugees from absolutism, may have a tendency to continue being absolutist, only now in their new direction ‚Äî to become ‚Äútankies,‚Äù in other words ‚Äî demanding purity and obeisance‚Ä¶ ugh. You _really_ must spend time educating them on the values of comity and diversity and tolerance, and on the fact that everyone‚Äòs path to enlightenment is different.)

Never endanger yourself! If you‚Äôre face-to-face and sense the people you‚Äôre persuading could turn violent, then run‚Ä¶ and live to teach another day! Unless you‚Äôre a public figure, there‚Äôs likely nothing to be gained from your martyrdom. But online, where you‚Äôre anonymous and can remain so? Maybe resist the temptation to ‚Äúown‚Äù people, and try badgering them with facts and reason and unfailing kindness instead. It really works.

That‚Äôs the path forward. Those people have been alienated by capitalism, so it‚Äôll take time and effort and there‚Äôll be disappointing failures along the way. But many of them _are_ reachable‚Ä¶ with kindness and love and a lot of patience. replies.author: @stephhhie17
replies.text:
@Mae_Dastardly The US  didn't "make it impossible for [Venezuela] to trade internationally" ‚Äî prior to 2019, they (and others including Canada, Mexico, and the EU) sanctioned a handful of individuals, mostly government officials, for human rights abuses, corruption, and drug & human trafficking.  PdVSA, the state-run oil company, 45 years ago, and after Hugo Ch√°vez took power there was a sort of "re-nationalization" of the oil industry in the early to mid 2000s, when the company came under more direct government control, private oil company assets were expropriated, and the profits were used to fund social programs.   Partial sanctions affecting PdVSA (which limited Americans from trading Venezuelan bonds and securities) did not come until 2017, and broader sanctions against PdVSA weren't issued until 2019.  

While there is plenty to criticize about sanctions, embargoes and the like, by 2017, the crises in Venezuela ‚Äî shortages of food and medicine, hyperinflation, declining oil production ‚Äî were already in full swing.  People have been blaming the state of Venezuela on US sanctions even before this, even though it would have been an impossibility.

author: @CSGraves
text:
I suspect that the folk who most need to see these videos - those prone to being persuaded by BPS and his ilk - won't have the patience to digest the thorough detail Three Arrows puts in. 
I'll also second the idea that alt-right sympathy is not a universal symptom of depression. There's a myriad of reasons for causal depression, in some cases, observing the current influence of alt-right politics and the ease with which some individuals buy into the ideology can be a real downer. And then there's the idea of strictly endogenous depression (which coincidentally plays well with producers of anti-depressant pharmaceuticals)... Certainly, extremists will often try to take advantage of people who are lost in life, and/or  so desperate to belong that they'll even embrace hateful paranoia, but not all of us are THAT desperate. My self-esteem might hover around rock bottom now and then, but this doesn't mean I'll degrade myself further by looking uncritically to xenophobic ideology as a panacea.

replies.author: @CSGraves
replies.text: Sorry to hear that. :-( I hope your brother grows out of those xenophobic ideas & finds his own direction.

replies.author: @CSGraves
replies.text:
@JeanClaude Clemenceau I agree that donning rose coloured spectacles is, in the long term, not helpful. Telling 'white lies' should only be a last resort to avoid self-destruction (or other-destruction for that matter), but carries the risk that the individual's ego may not survive the possibility of disillusionment further down the road. 
When one feels low, how tempting it might be to believe they are part of a "chosen people", inherently superior by birth! One could go from self-hate to resting on the laurels of merely existing in a heartbeat! One of the major downsides to this is having to constantly and artificially reinforce the mindset, not unlike Charlie Zelenoff insisting on his supreme pugilistic skills, no matter how many times he gets knocked down. I'm not averse to intellectual effort, provided it isn't wasted on such ideological dead-ends for the sake of self-worth.

replies.author: @CSGraves
replies.text:
i'm going to go out on a limb here and say the left does not have a monopoly on censorship. Book burnings in WWII take all of a nanosecond to spring to mind. The States even had book burnings, those of the work of WIlhelm Reich, for example, as well as attempts by conservative Christian groups to ban various titles. Note also the antebellum refusal of the US Postmaster General to carry abolitionist materials. Or the journalism ban during the invasion of Grenada in the 80's, the press restrictions during the Gulf War, the invasion of Iraq, or George W. Bush's censorship of climate studies. Pity that your excellent reply was lost by youtube and this one is all that was left behind, but the argument that only the left practices censorship is demonstrably false. 
Per Japanese racism, how happy were the Ainu people, when discriminated against by the Wa-jin? How happy were the 'comfort women' abducted from abroad and abused? A burglar may be happy to loot your home, a murderer happy to end their victim, but this happiness alone does not qualify their acts as good.

replies.text: On Twitter I read a post where the three mainstream political inclinations (left, liberalism, right, extremes aside) were reduced to one sentence which aims at describing the entire philosophy behind it. While this sort of reductive approach has its flaws, I think it is an interesting starting point. According to that post, conservatism is about "civilisation or barbarism". Since civilisation is currently established, the biggest threat to it is any kind of change. Could change lead to more barbarism? Who knows? Since betting on the future is a game where nobody has a definite answer, there is some a priori legitimacy to the conservative sorrows. (It is hard to disprove that things won't go wrong)

replies.text: What your thinking of is traditionalism. And while that ideology can exist on the right it can also exist on the left. I.E. returning to Obama era politics with Biden, returning to a better time. That time being subjectively better based on the ideological preference of an individual. Conservatism is an ideology that tends to be... conservative, as in conserving what you already have. Yes it will slow down progress but it also helps maintain what you have gained. I.E. freedoms of speech. Conservatives want to conserve freedom of speech in America. Because civil liberties are built on the ability to express your self freely in a society. Yet progressives in an attempt to progress beyond the current status quo attack freedom of speech. In a truly tolerant society conservatives and progressives would balance each other. Conservatives act as a counter to rapid progress. And progressives counter stagnate conservative ideology. The impasse we see in society is not a failure of conservative or progressive ideology but an acceptance of authoritarianism by the left to shift society into a state of rapid "progress". Which is why conservatism is often misrepresented, in order to demonize those who have differing views of the world.

replies.author: @Cretaal
replies.text:
@loltwest9423 I agree with the notion that I'm much warmer to BPS videos than three arrows. Don't get me wrong, I understand the points they're trying to get across in these dark times. You're very right that BPS does always end on that positive note of hope.

Nevertheless, I can still detect a strong hint of manipulation in his videos. The music he chooses, the narrative he pushes, the insults he gives out. It all paints a picture over time and I've been listening to his content for 2-3 years. He even chooses his tone of voice very methodically and it all points to someone very adept with human psychology using methodology seen in even late night infomercials. Beyond the narrative itself, I don't like how he tries to guide my emotions whilst delivering those views.

The silver lining feels like a call to action. I'll wager money this guy has The Art of War memorized. But that approach is purely speculation and gut instinct on my end, so take it with a grain of salt. I never trust anyone who appears to be too good at influencing.

Ever watch a video by the youtuber "chills" and notice his annoying cadence? He's not doing the best job with it, but he's using his upward inflections at the end of his sentences to build suspense (but it's just uncanny and jarring with him). I've seen a couple MGTOW youtubers do the same thing more effectively. BPS is reinforcing totality in every aspect of his video and the stimuli present therein. It's the biggest part of why I call him a sensationalist doomsayer for profit who lies by omission as well. The arguments he presented are complex and multifaceted to the enth degree but he is only capable of providing his one facet, his limited side. This would be fine if he displayed his views as opinions based on real world data, but with the nature of his presentation, it's all presented as alarming fact and the silver lining can also serve as a non overt call to action. But like I said, that's my limited view of it.

replies.author: @ArmoredSoul1
replies.text: Chalk O'holic I consider that an inherently an aspect of the state. I simply deny the fact that it is anarchy. The only reason those in power are immune to the consequences of their action is that the state protects them. The rich especially.

replies.author: @ArmoredSoul1
replies.text:
Chalk O'holic I believe corruption, abuse of power, and preferential treatment is inherent to the state. Any state. It's the reason most communist states fail, why the idea of regulated capitalism is a pipe dream, etc.

You can see it in our world today. Do you think the taxes get lower and lower on the rich, and that the rich occupy positions of power for no reason? Bribery, blackmail, abuse of power, etc. has existed as long as seats of power have existed. There are of course golden ages, and periods that such corruption wanes, but as long as a position means control over billions of lives, people with harmful desires will want to take the reigns.

It's why there's a common trope in media and writings that the one man who does not desire the crown should be the one to bear it exists. It's because those who yearn for the crown tend to be corrupt assholes, and outnumber those who want to take the reigns to help people.

The more diffuse the power is over a given community, the less chances for abuse there is. Monarchies and Theocracies are ripe for abuse for this reason.

replies.author: @ArmoredSoul1
replies.text:
‚ÄãChalk O'holic Of course, I know what BPS means when he says it. It doesn't make it any more absurd, and as I described there are descriptions for these things already in place. Anarcho-Tyranny is just an ultimately a meaningless combinations of bad things BPS doesn't like/sounds bad to his viewers.

Anarchy? That's when there are no laws. Tyranny? That's when I can't say the N-word.

Also, I don't think that's very abstract.

I live in the only first world country where medical care is run like a business, and rich people go to Canada for health care while buying our political system to ensure it stays that way. That's a pretty well-defined example.



Laws are changed to be made more lenient, not in a way that actually helps mitigate the harm it does to people, but in a way that clearly is designed to allow the rich to get away with it while the poor hold the bag.



Fines are definitely designed to allow rich and poor people to play by separate rules. A billionaire doesn't care about a 300 dollar speeding ticket, my girlfriend and I on our way to the hospital 2 months ago do. Sure, we will both most likely end up paying the fine(though it's less likely in the case of the rich), but we don't both face consequences.

Like Epstein and a lot of the rich and powerful got away with raping teenagers on his private jet for so long, but a massive percentage of people of color can't get away with smoking what is now a legalized substance, with many still in prison for what has become legal.

This is literally just the most modern examples of the state being inherently shit. Name a country and I'll name examples of how people of power do not have rules applied to them.

replies.author: @ArmoredSoul1
replies.text:
‚Äã Chalk O'holic  1) To make things clear I am an anarcho-communist. I don't want there to be a state beyond community driven communes where society rather than benefiting the greedy,  at the expense of the poor, instead is designed on working together. 

It isn't achievable in my lifetime but is my goal. I don't want to ignore the injustice of the state, or to counteract one injustice with another. I seek justice.

2) Speeding tickets and the like were examples. Not the key issue.

3) My main points overall were that unequal enforcement of laws isn't "anarcho-tyranny" it's the state acting as intended.

 (I'm not sure why you think the term has to do with saying the n word) The phrase we're mocking was coined by BPS, who is a white nationalist. He was talking about Brittain which does have Hate Speech laws.

(. But if that weren't the case, and one group uses a banned term and isn't punished, because it is a politically favored group,) Okay, but here is the key issue. When a member of a group uses a banned term in most of these cases in the modern world, it's a term under hate speech laws. They can be used biographically, in quoting of another person, and typically aren't pursued by law if a member of the groups targeted by that word use them. So I can't think of a case of this sort of thing in Brittain.

replies.author: @ArmoredSoul1
replies.text:
‚ÄãChalk O'holic Again I'm not saying it's illegitimate to analyze things. I'm talking in response to -this video- about Black Pidgeon Speaks, and him saying any country that doesn't allow you to be racist is a tyranny.

Like again. I'm an anarcho-communist, I say this not to draw some line in the sand, I say this because it defines my positions on these things. Yes, issues of state tyranny and corruption are important issues and should be weeded out, justice should be sought.

But in response to Britain being an anarcho-tyranny state, it isn't such in any way that isn't any worse than any other country or at least this has not been demonstrated.

It isn't a failed state, people aren't being burned at the stake, the level of corruption is casual at best. It's fucked up, yeah, but BPS isn't the person or the framing to talk about it.

Lastly, yes, the state doing something condradictory to its laws is the norm and inherent to the state. For example, the most basic example. If a group of bakers, masoners, and construction workers burn a man at the stake for murder, they are commiting a crime (I agree it's a crime against humanity especially without fair trial) but if a police kills him there is first a series of investigations to see if it is a crime or not because the state has the inherent contradiction and monopoly on violence.

You can debate on if that contradiction is valid or invalid, but the contradiction exists.
